title: Sambucus racemosa subsp. racemosa
text:
Sambucus racemosa" subsp. "racemosa is a <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> of "<a href="Sambucus%20racemosa">Sambucus racemosa</a>", with the common names European red elder and Pacific red elderberry.
Distribution.
The plant is native to <a href="Europe">Europe</a> and to <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, in <a href="Western%20Canada">Western Canada</a> and the <a href="Western%20United%20States">Western United States</a>.
Locations it is found in include <a href="Albania">Albania</a>; <a href="Armenia">Armenia</a>; <a href="Austria">Austria</a>; <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>; <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>; <a href="California">California</a>; <a href="Canada">Canada</a>; <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>; <a href="France">France</a>; <a href="Germany">Germany</a>; <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>; <a href="Italy">Italy</a>; the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>; <a href="Poland">Poland</a>; <a href="Romania">Romania</a>; <a href="Spain">Spain</a>; <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>; the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, and the present day states of former <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>.
Taxonomy.
This particular <a href="trinomial%20name%23In%20botany">trinomial name</a> was automatically created by the subsequent discoveries of other subspecies within the <a href="binomial%20name">binomial name</a>. It is used to set it apart as the original species. Trinomials such as this are called <a href="autonym%20%28botany%29">autonyms</a>.
